questions.text: 1. A 58-year-old male, known case of diabetes mellitus and hypertension, presents with nasal bleeding. If the initial conservative management, such as nasal packing, was not successful in controlling the bleed, which of the following arteries should most importantly be ligated to control the bleed?
questions.solution:
The most important artery to be ligated in a case of epistaxis that is not controlled by conservative management is the sphenopalatine artery, as it is the main artery contributing to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

Little's area is the most common site of epistaxis. It is present in the anteroinferior part of the septum. Four arteries (anterior ethmoidal, septal branch of superior labial, septal branch of sphenopalatine, and greater palatine) anastomose here to form Kiesselbach’s plexus.

The image below shows the blood supply of the nasal septum and areas of epistaxis.



The first step in treating epistaxis is to pinch the nose with the thumb and index finger for about 5 minutes. The patient should sit leaning slightly forward over a basin to spit out blood and breathe through the mouth (Hippocratic or Trotter’s method).



If the bleeding point is localized, cauterization can be done with electrocautery. In cases of uncontrolled bleeding or when the bleeding is posterior into the throat, anterior or posterior nasal packing may be required, respectively. If bleeding continues despite these measures, endoscopic procedures or vessel ligation close to the bleeding point can be considered.





The recommended hierarchy of ligation of vessels in a patient with epistaxis is given below:

Sphenopalatine artery ↓ Internal maxillary artery (The greater palatine artery is a branch of this artery, option D) ↓ External carotid artery ↓ Anterior ethmoidal artery (option A)  ↓ Posterior ethmoidal artery (option B)

The sphenopalatine artery is ligated first through a trans-nasal endoscope (transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation) at the sphenopalatine foramen, which is situated at the posterior end of the middle turbinate.

However, if the bleeding persists, internal maxillary artery ligation is done at the pterygopalatine fossa via the Caldwell-Luc approach. If bleeding is still not controlled, external carotid artery ligation is done just above the origin of the superior thyroid artery.

If the bleeding site is located superior to the level of the middle turbinate, the anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries should be ligated via Lynch incision in the medial wall of the orbit.

questions.text: 2. A 20-year-old patient presents with recurrent ear discharge and conductive hearing loss with 30 dB loss. Which of the following is the management of choice?
questions.solution:
Myringoplasty is the management of choice in this patient.

The given clinical scenario, along with the otoscopy image, points towards a diagnosis of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) with subtotal perforation of the tympanic membrane, with all ossicles intact. The management of choice in this condition is Myringoplasty or type I tympanoplasty.

Myringoplasty is the closure of a perforation in the pars tensa of the tympanic membrane, which is done by placing a graft over or under the remaining tympanic membrane. Myringoplasty techniques are based on the relation of the graft to the lamina propria of the tympanic membrane remnants and the fibrous annulus.

The grafts used in tympanoplasty include temporalis fascia (most common), areolar fascia overlying the temporal fascia, tragal perichondrium, cartilage, vein, and periosteum.

In the underlay technique, the graft is placed medial to the annulus. Whereas, in the overlay technique, the graft is placed lateral to the annulus. The graft is medial to the malleus in both techniques.



Other options:

Option B: Modified radical mastoidectomy is a surgical procedure performed to remove disease from the middle ear and mastoid, often due to chronic infection or cholesteatoma, while preserving or reconstructing the middle ear structures to maintain hearing. The surgery involves removal of the disease from the attic and the antrum, and exteriorization of the mastoid cavity to the external auditory meatus by removal of the posterior meatal wall and the lateral attic wall.

Option C: Atticotomy, also known as epitympanotomy, is a procedure in which the lateral wall of the attic or the epitympanum is removed. This is done in the cases of limited cholesteatoma.

Option D: Exploratory tympanotomy is a diagnostic surgical procedure that enables direct evaluation of the middle ear, allowing the surgeon to plan and perform appropriate treatment based on intraoperative findings. It is typically indicated in patients with conductive hearing loss who have a normal tympanic membrane, normal tympanometry, and unremarkable temporal bone CT scans.

Pearl PM0433: Zollner and Wullstein’s classification/ Types of tympanoplasty

Type Findings Procedure
Graft placed over
Type I (or) Myringoplasty All ossicles are intact Over/ under remnant TM over the handle of malleus
Type II Malleus eroded Over the remnant malleus/ incus
Type III (or) Columella (or) Myringostapediopexy Malleus & incus absent Over stapes superstructure
Type IV (or) Cavum minor All ossicles eroded Over ET and the round window, leaving mobile footplate exposed
Type V (or) Fenestration surgery Fixed footplate An opening made in the lateral semicircular canal (an alternative pathway)
Type VI (or) Sono-Inversion --- The round window is left exposed and receives sound and the oval window is covered (reversed pathway)


Type III is called columella because it resembles the middle ear of birds. They have a single ossicle. Type VI is not part of the original Zollner-Wullstein classification. It is a recent addition.

Image showing different types of tympanoplasty:



SCC: Semicircular canal.

questions.text: 3. An industrial worker presented with hearing loss. Rinne’s test was negative on the left side and positive on the right side. Weber lateralised to the left side. Pure tone audiometry was done with results as shown below. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The tuning fork test and pure tone audiometry (PTA) findings are suggestive of left-sided conductive deafness. 

Interpretation of the tuning fork tests:

* Rinne's Test: Negative on the left side (BC > AC) and positive on the right side (AC > BC).

* Weber's Test: Lateralized to the left ear (worse ear).

Interpretation of the above audiogram:

* Blue color indicates the left ear.

* ] indicates BC (bone conduction) and the threshold is <25dB. BC is normal, which means the sensorineural pathway is normal.

* × indicates AC (air conduction), and the threshold is >15 dB, and hence AC is abnormal.

* So, it indicates conductive deafness.

* The air-bone gap is a feature of conductive hearing loss.

* Hence, the chart is suggestive of left-sided conductive deafness.

Pearl PM1750: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its intensity can be increased or decreased by 5dB.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:

* For AC: 15 dB

* For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:



 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve


Pearl PM1800: Tuning fork tests

Tests Normal
Conductive 
loss
Sensorineural
loss
Rinne AC > BC (Rinne +) BC > AC (Rinne -) AC > BC (Rinne +)
Weber Center Lateralized to the affected ear Lateralized to the normal ear
Absolute bone conduction Normal Normal Reduced
Schwabach Normal Lengthened Shortened
Bing Positive Negative Positive
Gelle Positive Negative (ossicular lesions) Positive


AC- Air conduction; BC- Bone conduction.

questions.text: 4. A 75-year-old male smoker presents with complaints of hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. He is diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma and undergoes surgery. What is the surgical procedure?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a post-operative tracheal stump created for breathing in patients undergoing total laryngectomy for laryngeal carcinoma.

In total laryngectomy, the entire larynx, including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles, and one or more rings of trachea, are removed. The pharyngeal wall is repaired, and the tracheal stump is sutured to the skin to allow respiration. 

The indications of total laryngectomy are as follows:

* T3 lesions

* All T4 lesions

* Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage

* Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement

* Lesions of the posterior commissure 

* Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery

* Transglottic cancers with cord fixation

It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastasis.

Other options:

Option A: Partial laryngectomy is a conservation procedure that involves the excision of the vocal cord and anterior commissure region in partial front lateral laryngectomy and the excision of supraglottis in partial horizontal laryngectomy. This surgery is performed to conserve the voice and avoid a permanent tracheal opening. 

Option B: Percutaneous tracheostomy is done in ICU patients under sedation when the patient is already intubated and being monitored. The image below shows the procedure of percutaneous tracheostomy.



Option C: Standard tracheostomy can be therapeutic (used for respiratory obstruction, remove tracheobronchial secretions or assisted ventilation) and prophylactic (for anticipated respiratory obstruction or aspiration of blood or pharyngeal secretions).

questions.text: 5. A male child in his 2ⁿᵈ decade presents with recurrent profuse nasal bleeding in the right nasal cavity and right nasal obstruction. Endoscopy shows a globular mass in the right nasal cavity occupying the posterior choanae and nasopharynx. MRI shows anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the MRI findings and transnasal endoscopic image, is suggestive of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor. It is predominantly seen in adolescent males and is thought to be testosterone-dependent. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity near the sphenopalatine foramen. 

The clinical features include epistaxis, progressive nasal obstruction, and denasal speech. Other symptoms include conductive hearing loss, broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis leading to frog-face deformity, cheek swelling, and involvement of II, III, IV, and VI cranial nerves.

Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is the investigation of choice that reveals anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/Holman Miller sign), which is pathognomonic of angiofibroma as shown below.



Carotid angiography shows the extent of the tumor with its vascularity. The feeding vessels mostly come from the external carotid artery. In large tumors with intracranial extension, vessels come from the internal carotid system. 

Biopsy of the mass is avoided due to the risk of bleeding. Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Embolization of the vessels can be done prior to surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding during the surgery. Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy can also be considered.

Other options:

Option B: Antrochoanal polyp (Killian's polyp) arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum. They are usually unilateral and are seen in children and young adults. They present with unilateral nasal obstruction with minimal to no bleeding. X-rays of the paranasal sinuses show opacity of the maxillary sinus.

Option C: Rhinoscleroma is caused by a gram-negative coccobacillus, Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It causes this progressive granulomatous infection starting in the nose and extending into the upper respiratory tract. It presents initially with foul-smelling nasal discharge, and then with granulomatous nodules in the nose, giving it a woody feeling. The last stage is the cicatricial stage, with stenosis of the nares and adhesions in the nose. 

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous disease caused by an aquatic protist, Rhinosporidium seeberi, that is endemic in South India. It also presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and discharge, but examination will show a mulberry or strawberry mass with white dots and subcutaneous nodules on the skin. The biopsy will show a sporangium with sporangiospores.

Pearl PM1297: Antrochoanal Polyp

* Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy

* Usually affects children

* Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum

* Clinical features:

* Usually single and unilateral

* Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana

* Mucoid nasal discharge

* Hyponasal voice

* Findings:

* Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy

* Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx

* Investigation: Nasal endoscopy: Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated. NonContrast CT scan: Gives exquisite bony detail of the paranasal sinus anatomy. It is the primary diagnostic imaging modality.

* Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: 6. Identify the structure marked with arrow as 'f':
questions.solution:
The given image is a barium swallow image of the hypopharynx, and the marked arrow (f) shows the Pyriform sinus.

The pyriform fossa lies on either side of the larynx and extends from the pharyngoepiglottic fold to the upper end of the esophagus. It is bound laterally by the thyrohyoid membrane and the thyroid cartilage and medially by the aryepiglottic fold, the posterolateral surfaces of the arytenoid and cricoid cartilages. It forms the lateral channel for food. 

The internal laryngeal nerve lies submucosally in the lateral wall of the sinus and is easily accessible for local anaesthesia. The pain is referred to the ear in the carcinoma of the pyriform sinus through the internal laryngeal nerve. Foreign bodies may lodge in the piriform fossa. 

The image below shows lateral and AP images of the pharynx demonstrating typical anatomy encountered during a barium swallow.

* a- Tongue base

* b- Epiglottis

* c- Vallecula containing a small amount of residual barium

* d- Hyoid bone

* e- Laryngeal vestibule coated in barium, consistent with laryngeal penetration

* f- Piriform sinuses containing a small amount of residual barium

* g- Vocal cords coated in barium

* h- Barium coating the anterior aspect of the trachea, consistent with tracheal aspiration



The image below shows a cut section of the human larynx.



Other options:

Option B: Valeculla are cup-shaped depressions lying between the base of the tongue and the anterior surface of the epiglottis.

Option C: Epiglottis is a leaf-like, yellow elastic cartilage that forms the anterior wall of the laryngeal inlet. It is attached to the body of the hyoid bone. A stalk-like process of the epiglottis (petiole) attaches the epiglottis to the thyroid angle just above the attachment of the vocal cords. 

Option D: Thyroid cartilage has two alae that are fused anteriorly.

questions.text: 7. A 2-year-old was brought to the ED following choking on a peanut. The child was unresponsive. What is the next step for managing this patient?
questions.solution:
If a choking child is brought to the hospital in an unresponsive state, immediately activate the hospital’s emergency response system and start CPR without delay, beginning with chest compressions.

When the choking child becomes unresponsive, CPR should be started with 30 chest compressions, followed by an airway examination to identify the presence of a foreign body. Two rescue breaths should be attempted. If the airway obstruction is still not relieved, then CPR should be restarted and continued until the airway obstruction is relieved.

For an infant or child with a foreign body obstruction, the next step depends on the severity and consciousness of the patient:

Group Severity Consciousness Recommendation
Child Mild Conscious Let the child cough to clear the airway while watching for signs of a severe obstruction
Child Severe Conscious Give abdominal thrusts (option B) repeatedly until the object comes out or the child becomes unresponsive
Infant Severe Conscious Give repeated cycles of 5 back slaps (option A) followed by 5 chest thrusts until the object is removed or the child becomes unresponsive
Infant/ Child Severe Unresponsive

Begin CPR with chest compressions (option D).

If the emergency response has not been activated, do so after 2 minutes of CPR.

When opening the airway to give breaths, remove any foreign object that you can see.

Blind finger sweeping may be hazardous as it can push the object further down the airway.


During laryngoscopy, if the foreign body is visible above the vocal cords, an attempt should be made to remove it with Magill forceps. If the foreign body is below the vocal cords, an attempt should be made to push the foreign body more distally to reestablish a patent airway. This will allow for rescue oxygenation and ventilation while preparing for more definitive management.

Demonstration of back slaps in an Infant:



Demonstration of chest thrusts in an Infant:



Other options:

Option C: Endotracheal intubation is an advanced intervention and is not part of routine first-line management.

questions.text: 8. A boy sustained a fracture, and an X-ray was done. The lateral X-ray of the nasal bone shows a nasal bone fracture. Which forceps are used for immediate correction?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray is suggestive of a nasal bone fracture. Walsham forceps is mainly used to reduce nasal bone fractures.

Nasal bone fractures usually result from direct trauma such as fights, falls, sports injuries, or road accidents. Clinical examination may show deformity, swelling, bruising, and nasal obstruction. Imaging may aid in the diagnosis, but the diagnosis is mainly made on the basis of physical examination.

Nasal fracture management involves closed reduction, ideally before the appearance of edema or once it subsides, using instruments like elevators and forceps to realign bones. Simple, non-displaced fractures may not require treatment, while unstable fractures need intranasal packing and external splints for support.



Open reduction is reserved for cases where closed methods fail or for complex injuries. Prompt drainage of a septal hematoma is essential to prevent complications.

Asch's forceps is used to reduce nasal septum fractures.



Other options:

Option A: Tilley’s forceps is used for anterior nasal packing in epistaxis.



Option C: Bayonet forceps are used to examine, grasp or extract tissues and foreign materials from within the ear and nasal cavities.



Option D: Luc’s forceps is used in the Caldwell-Luc operation, submucous resection, and polypectomy.
